Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that cooperation with others depends on shared understanding of social conventions, including turn-taking language, which vary according to the degree of formality
Elaboration: Recognising and using collaborative language in group and pair work; for example, initiating a topic, changing a topic through negotiation, affirming other speakers and building on their comments, asking relevant questions, providing useful feedback, prompting and checking individual and group understanding
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •culturally sensitive introduction to collaborative learning protocols, if they are accustomed to school environments where collaborating with other students is not expected

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that cooperation with others depends on shared understanding of social conventions, including turn-taking language, which vary according to the degree of formality
Elaboration: Understanding some first nations australian cultural protocols, cultural practices, specific roles and ways of interacting and speaking

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how the language of evaluation and emotion, such as modal verbs, can be varied to be more or less forceful
Elaboration: Exploring how modal verbs; for example, "must", "might" and "could" indicate degrees of probability or obligation
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •substituting different modal verbs in a sentence and explaining how meaning is changed; for example ‘We must arrive by 11am’; ‘We might arrive by 11am’.

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how the language of evaluation and emotion, such as modal verbs, can be varied to be more or less forceful
Elaboration: Exploring how modal verbs; for example, "must", "might" and "could" indicate degrees of probability or obligation
EALDElaboration: •discuss and provide examples of the use of low modality to persuade or be polite, for example. Would you mind speaking more quietly?

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how the language of evaluation and emotion, such as modal verbs, can be varied to be more or less forceful
Elaboration: Recognising how choice of adverbs, nouns and verbs present different evaluations of characters in texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how the language of evaluation and emotion, such as modal verbs, can be varied to be more or less forceful
Elaboration: Exploring examples of language that demonstrate a range of emotions and positions, and building a vocabulary to express judgements about characters or events; for example, "the wizard was cunning, expert, inventive"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe how texts across the curriculum use different language features and structures relevant to their purpose
Elaboration: Identifying the stages of a basic argument: introduction, argument one, argument 2 and conclusion
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •using model texts to demonstrate and explain text structures, appropriate language choices and sentence structures.

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe how texts across the curriculum use different language features and structures relevant to their purpose
Elaboration: Identifying the stages of a basic argument: introduction, argument one, argument 2 and conclusion
EALDElaboration: •use of vocabulary clines

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Describe how texts across the curriculum use different language features and structures relevant to their purpose
Elaboration: Describing the typical text structure and language features of factual recounts, autobiographies, information reports, narratives, personal responses to literary texts (with reasons), sequential explanations, verse poetry and simple arguments, and describe their purposes

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that paragraphs are a key organisational feature of the stages of written texts, grouping related information together
Elaboration: Recognising that longer informative texts are organised into paragraphs which begin with a topic sentence that predicts how the paragraph will develop, and is then elaborated on in various ways

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that paragraphs are a key organisational feature of the stages of written texts, grouping related information together
Elaboration: Recognising that paragraphs in narrative texts vary in length and do not always follow a predictable structure

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand that paragraphs are a key organisational feature of the stages of written texts, grouping related information together
Elaboration: Examining models of well-constructed paragraphs and identifying their features

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the purpose of layout features in print and digital texts and the words used for navigation
Elaboration: Examining the words used as hyperlinks
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •inclusion of images that reflect the cultural diversity of the students in the class

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the purpose of layout features in print and digital texts and the words used for navigation
Elaboration: Discussing words used as headings and subheadings in digital and print information texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the purpose of layout features in print and digital texts and the words used for navigation
Elaboration: Discussing words used for chapter headings in narratives

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that a clause is a unit of grammar usually containing a subject and a verb that need to agree
Elaboration: Identifying clauses in texts by locating verbs and the key words that link to the verbs; for example, "while the cat slept, the mouse scurried across the path."
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to identify adverbial phrases in main clauses by asking ‘When? Where? or How? For example ‘in the playground’ ‘The girls ran (Where?) …in the playground.’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that a clause is a unit of grammar usually containing a subject and a verb that need to agree
Elaboration: Identifying that a singular subject has a singular verb and a plural subject has a plural verb; for example, "the girls play cricket." "the girl plays cricket."

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how verbs represent different processes: for doing, feeling, thinking, saying and relating
Elaboration: Exploring "doing" and "saying" verbs in narrative texts to understand how they give information about what characters do and say

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how verbs represent different processes: for doing, feeling, thinking, saying and relating
Elaboration: Exploring the use of sensing verbs and how they allow readers to understand what characters think and feel; for example, "he remembered his first day at school."

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how verbs represent different processes: for doing, feeling, thinking, saying and relating
Elaboration: Exploring the use of relating verbs in constructing definitions and descriptions; for example, identifying the relating verb "is" or "are", "has" or "have" in descriptions of animals

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand how verbs represent different processes: for doing, feeling, thinking, saying and relating
Elaboration: Identifying different types of verbs and the way they control meaning in a clause

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that verbs are anchored in time through tense
Elaboration: Learning how time is represented through the tense of a verb; for example, "she arrived." "she is arriving." and adverbials of time; for example, "she arrived yesterday." "she is arriving in the morning."
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •support to understand that regular English verbs follow predictable patterns when written in past tense  (for example adding ‘ed’). Irregular verbs are commonly used, but have challenging and unpredictable forms in the past tense;  for example ‘teach – taught’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that verbs are anchored in time through tense
Elaboration: Learning how time is represented through the tense of a verb; for example, "she arrived." "she is arriving." and adverbials of time; for example, "she arrived yesterday." "she is arriving in the morning."
EALDElaboration: •multiple opportunities to practise the use of tense in contextualised, structured verbal contexts

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that verbs are anchored in time through tense
Elaboration: Learning that tenses for some verbs are formed by changing the word; for example, "she catches the ball." "she caught the ball."

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify how images extend the meaning of a text
Elaboration: Recognising how the relationship between characters can be depicted in images through the positioning of the characters; for example, facing each other or facing away from each other, the distance between them, the relative size, one character looking up (or down) at the other (power relationships), facial expressions and body gestures

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Identify how images extend the meaning of a text
Elaboration: Recognising how images construct a relationship with the viewer through direct gaze into the viewer's eyes inviting involvement, and how close-ups are more engaging than distanced images which can suggest alienation or loneliness

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Extend topic-specific and technical vocabulary and know that words can have different meanings in different contexts
Elaboration: Identifying and using technical words to describe length; for example, metric units of length - "millimetre" and "centimetre"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •learning new words in context, as words and phrases take their meanings from the context of the sentences and texts they appear in and adding them to personal dictionaries

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Extend topic-specific and technical vocabulary and know that words can have different meanings in different contexts
Elaboration: Identifying and using technical words to describe length; for example, metric units of length - "millimetre" and "centimetre"
EALDElaboration: •experiencing new words in the context of texts by substituting the new vocabulary for synonyms in the text; for example ‘hot’ weather –’ humid’ or’ tropical’ weather ‘hot- tempered’ -‘’annoyed’

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Extend topic-specific and technical vocabulary and know that words can have different meanings in different contexts
Elaboration: Identifying and using words to describe features of narratives; for example, "character", "plot" and "setting"

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Extend topic-specific and technical vocabulary and know that words can have different meanings in different contexts
Elaboration: Identifying words that have different meanings in different contexts; for example, "warm temperature" and "warm character"

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Extend topic-specific and technical vocabulary and know that words can have different meanings in different contexts
Elaboration: Extending vocabulary by adding prefixes and suffixes to base words; for example, "different", "differently" and "difference"

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that apostrophes signal missing letters in contractions and apostrophes are used to show singular and plural possession
Elaboration: Using apostrophes to create contractions; for example, "do not" - "don't", "will not" - "won't" and "o'clock" - "of the clock"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •demonstrating how two words are blended to create a contraction;’ for example ‘did no’t- ‘didn't’ and how the contraction does not alter the meaning; for example  ‘She was not on the train’. ‘ She wasn’t on the train’.

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that apostrophes signal missing letters in contractions and apostrophes are used to show singular and plural possession
Elaboration: Using apostrophes to show singular possession; for example, "my friend's book" and "the princess's shoe"

Subject: English
Substrand: Language for expressing and developing ideas
ContentDescription: Understand that apostrophes signal missing letters in contractions and apostrophes are used to show singular and plural possession
Elaboration: Using apostrophes to show plural possession; for example, "the bees' hive" and "the princesses' shoes"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss characters, events and settings in different contexts in literature by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Exploring the ways wide-ranging authors tell the same story, identifying variations in the storyline
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •models of sentence stems to support their participation in discussions; for example “ I think the character in this story...’ ;  ‘The author of this story ,,,,’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss characters, events and settings in different contexts in literature by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Discussing characters and their relationship with country/place and families in literature by first nations australian authors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss characters, events and settings in different contexts in literature by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Discussing similarities and differences in the way the wolf is portrayed in different versions of children's stories by wide-ranging world authors

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss characters, events and settings in different contexts in literature by first nations australian and wide-ranging australian and world authors and illustrators
Elaboration: Exploring the ways australian settings are portrayed in stories

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Discuss connections between personal experiences and character experiences in literary texts, and share personal preferences
Elaboration: Discussing relevant prior knowledge and past experiences to make meaningful connections to the people, places, events, issues and ideas in texts

Subject: English
Substrand: Engaging with and responding to literature
ContentDescription: Discuss connections between personal experiences and character experiences in literary texts, and share personal preferences
Elaboration: Selecting and discussing favourite texts and explaining reasons for assigning greater or lesser merit to particular texts or types of texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how an author uses language and illustrations to portray characters and settings in texts, and explore how the settings and events influence the mood of the narrative
Elaboration: Identifying and discussing how the use of descriptive language creates setting and influences atmosphere and draws readers into events that follow; for example, "the castle loomed dark and forbidding."
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •demonstrations of conventions in use of adjectives. Descriptions of characters and settings often require use of adjectives. English has a preferred order for adjectives in noun groups, which is often intuitive to native speakers; for example ‘an old, stone castle’ not a ‘stone, old castle.’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss how an author uses language and illustrations to portray characters and settings in texts, and explore how the settings and events influence the mood of the narrative
Elaboration: Discussing the language used to describe the traits of characters in stories, their actions and motivations; for example, "claire was so lonely; she desperately wanted a pet, so she hatched a plan to get what she wanted."

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss the effects of some literary devices used to enhance meaning and shape the reader's reaction, including rhythm and onomatopoeia in poetry and prose
Elaboration: Discussing the effects of imagery in texts; for example, the use of imagery related to nature in haiku poems
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •clear explanations of figurative or idiomatic use of language, even with commonly used or familiar examples; for example ‘as clear as mud’; ‘fought like cats and dogs’.

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Discuss the effects of some literary devices used to enhance meaning and shape the reader's reaction, including rhythm and onomatopoeia in poetry and prose
Elaboration: Generating questions to discuss effects; for example, "why does the poet use onomatopoeia in this line of the poem?"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit imaginative texts using or adapting language features, characters, settings, plot structures and ideas encountered in literary texts
Elaboration: Drawing on literary texts read, viewed and listened to for inspiration and ideas to create texts
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •use of colour-coding to focus proof reading and editing on one aspect at a time, for example a colour for checking spelling; a colour for checking grammar

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit imaginative texts using or adapting language features, characters, settings, plot structures and ideas encountered in literary texts
Elaboration: Drawing on literary texts read, viewed and listened to for inspiration and ideas to create texts
EALDElaboration: •teacher-led joint construction of texts and partially filled text scaffolds

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit imaginative texts using or adapting language features, characters, settings, plot structures and ideas encountered in literary texts
Elaboration: Adapting texts read, viewed and listened to by changing the setting or revising an ending

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Create and edit imaginative texts using or adapting language features, characters, settings, plot structures and ideas encountered in literary texts
Elaboration: Discussing characters encountered in literary texts and sharing ideas about how those characters may be a model for their own writing

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise how texts can be created for similar purposes but different audiences
Elaboration: Identifying the ways in which a safety campaign varies depending on its audience; for example, comparing how a road safety campaign for adults driving is different to a road safety campaign for children crossing the road

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise how texts can be created for similar purposes but different audiences
Elaboration: Identifying how the instructions for assembling and using toys vary according to the age of the user

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills to contribute to conversations and discussions, to share information and ideas
Elaboration: Building on and connecting ideas and opinions expressed by others
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •modelling and supporting language used to contribute and respond during discussion, for example using sentence starters

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills to contribute to conversations and discussions, to share information and ideas
Elaboration: Building on and connecting ideas and opinions expressed by others
EALDElaboration: •ensuring class members are aware of social and cultural sensitivities that may impact interactions; for example protocols around social distance

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills to contribute to conversations and discussions, to share information and ideas
Elaboration: Building on and connecting ideas and opinions expressed by others
EALDElaboration: •engaging in role play

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills to contribute to conversations and discussions, to share information and ideas
Elaboration: Listening actively, including listening for specific information, recognising the value of others' contributions and responding through comments, recounts and summaries of information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills to contribute to conversations and discussions, to share information and ideas
Elaboration: Learning the specific speaking or listening skills of different group roles; for example, group leader, note taker and reporter

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use interaction skills to contribute to conversations and discussions, to share information and ideas
Elaboration: Using language appropriately in different situations; for example, explaining a procedure to a group, engaging in a game with friends

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the audience and purpose of imaginative, informative and persuasive texts through their use of language features and/or images
Elaboration: Identifying words, phrases and images intended to persuade listeners, viewers or readers

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the audience and purpose of imaginative, informative and persuasive texts through their use of language features and/or images
Elaboration: Identifying features of advertisements that target children

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Identify the audience and purpose of imaginative, informative and persuasive texts through their use of language features and/or images
Elaboration: Identifying the purpose of an imaginative text; for example, identifying the purpose of a fable

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read a range of texts using phonic, semantic and grammatical knowledge to read accurately and fluently, re-reading and self-correcting when required
Elaboration: Using phonic knowledge, word knowledge, vocabulary and grammatical knowledge to read unknown words

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Read a range of texts using phonic, semantic and grammatical knowledge to read accurately and fluently, re-reading and self-correcting when required
Elaboration: Reading a wider range of texts from different learning areas, including chapter books and informative texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies when listening and viewing to build literal and inferred meaning, and begin to evaluate texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context, text structures and language features
Elaboration: Making predictions about a text, drawing on knowledge of the topic, subject-specific vocabulary and experience of texts on the same topic
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •demonstrations of how to connect key words and phrases, across a text, in order to draw inferences; for example connecting ‘heart pounding’; ‘trembling hands’ and ‘sucking in a breath’ to infer feelings of fear.

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies when listening and viewing to build literal and inferred meaning, and begin to evaluate texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context, text structures and language features
Elaboration: Determining important ideas, events or details in texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies when listening and viewing to build literal and inferred meaning, and begin to evaluate texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context, text structures and language features
Elaboration: Learning new content from reading and listening and asking questions to expand understanding

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies when listening and viewing to build literal and inferred meaning, and begin to evaluate texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context, text structures and language features
Elaboration: Comparing and contrasting how different texts present similar ideas or information

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies when listening and viewing to build literal and inferred meaning, and begin to evaluate texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context, text structures and language features
Elaboration: Drawing inferences using evidence from the text and prior knowledge and experience; for example, making predictions about a character's likely actions or about the content of tabbed pages on a website

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use comprehension strategies when listening and viewing to build literal and inferred meaning, and begin to evaluate texts by drawing on a growing knowledge of context, text structures and language features
Elaboration: Determining the relevance of a text for a particular task

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish imaginative, informative and persuasive written and multimodal texts, using visual features, appropriate form and layout, with ideas grouped in simple paragraphs, mostly correct tense, topic-specific vocabulary and correct spelling of most high-frequency and phonetically regular words
Elaboration: Gathering information and ideas about a topic in preparation for writing, which may include online and digital sources
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to jointly construct texts with teacher support

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish imaginative, informative and persuasive written and multimodal texts, using visual features, appropriate form and layout, with ideas grouped in simple paragraphs, mostly correct tense, topic-specific vocabulary and correct spelling of most high-frequency and phonetically regular words
Elaboration: Gathering information and ideas about a topic in preparation for writing, which may include online and digital sources
EALDElaboration: •more comprehensive scaffolds to guide organising the text or choices of vocabulary

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish imaginative, informative and persuasive written and multimodal texts, using visual features, appropriate form and layout, with ideas grouped in simple paragraphs, mostly correct tense, topic-specific vocabulary and correct spelling of most high-frequency and phonetically regular words
Elaboration: Selecting appropriate text structure for a writing purpose and sequencing content for clarity and to have an impact on an audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish imaginative, informative and persuasive written and multimodal texts, using visual features, appropriate form and layout, with ideas grouped in simple paragraphs, mostly correct tense, topic-specific vocabulary and correct spelling of most high-frequency and phonetically regular words
Elaboration: Using appropriate simple and compound sentences to express and combine ideas

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish imaginative, informative and persuasive written and multimodal texts, using visual features, appropriate form and layout, with ideas grouped in simple paragraphs, mostly correct tense, topic-specific vocabulary and correct spelling of most high-frequency and phonetically regular words
Elaboration: Using vocabulary, including topic-specific vocabulary, relevant to the type of text and purpose

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish imaginative, informative and persuasive written and multimodal texts, using visual features, appropriate form and layout, with ideas grouped in simple paragraphs, mostly correct tense, topic-specific vocabulary and correct spelling of most high-frequency and phonetically regular words
Elaboration: Using digital tools to plan, sequence, compose and edit texts

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish imaginative, informative and persuasive written and multimodal texts, using visual features, appropriate form and layout, with ideas grouped in simple paragraphs, mostly correct tense, topic-specific vocabulary and correct spelling of most high-frequency and phonetically regular words
Elaboration: Using print and online dictionaries and spellcheck to edit spelling, realising that spellcheck accuracy depends on understanding the word function; for example, "there" or "their" and "rain" or "reign"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, edit and publish imaginative, informative and persuasive written and multimodal texts, using visual features, appropriate form and layout, with ideas grouped in simple paragraphs, mostly correct tense, topic-specific vocabulary and correct spelling of most high-frequency and phonetically regular words
Elaboration: Checking for correct use of apostrophes for contractions and to indicate possession

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver short oral and/or multimodal presentations to inform, express opinions or tell stories, using a clear structure, details to elaborate ideas, topic-specific and precise vocabulary, visual features and appropriate tone, pace, pitch and volume
Elaboration: Researching a topic to prepare an oral or multimodal presentation

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver short oral and/or multimodal presentations to inform, express opinions or tell stories, using a clear structure, details to elaborate ideas, topic-specific and precise vocabulary, visual features and appropriate tone, pace, pitch and volume
Elaboration: Planning the sequence of ideas and information using techniques such as storyboards

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver short oral and/or multimodal presentations to inform, express opinions or tell stories, using a clear structure, details to elaborate ideas, topic-specific and precise vocabulary, visual features and appropriate tone, pace, pitch and volume
Elaboration: Adjusting tone and pace to purpose and audience

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Plan, create, rehearse and deliver short oral and/or multimodal presentations to inform, express opinions or tell stories, using a clear structure, details to elaborate ideas, topic-specific and precise vocabulary, visual features and appropriate tone, pace, pitch and volume
Elaboration: Explaining ideas to a peer when planning a presentation

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Write words using joined letters that are clearly formed and consistent in size

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to apply knowledge of phoneme-grapheme (sound-letter) relationships, syllables and blending and segmenting to fluently read and write multisyllabic words with more complex letter patterns
Elaboration: Reading and writing more complex words with consonant digraphs and consonant blends; for example, "shrinking", "against" and "rocket"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •opportunities to hear and practise saying multisyllabic words prior to reading and writing,

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to apply knowledge of phoneme-grapheme (sound-letter) relationships, syllables and blending and segmenting to fluently read and write multisyllabic words with more complex letter patterns
Elaboration: Reading and writing consonant digraphs representing different sounds; for example, "machine", "change" and "school"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to apply knowledge of common base words, prefixes, suffixes and generalisations for adding a suffix to a base word to read and comprehend new multimorphemic words
Elaboration: Understanding how to use knowledge of prefixes to change the meaning of a base word; for example, "undone", "remove" and "misunderstand"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •manipulating words into their morphemic chunks; for example ‘write’; ‘writer’ ‘rewrite’

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to apply knowledge of common base words, prefixes, suffixes and generalisations for adding a suffix to a base word to read and comprehend new multimorphemic words
Elaboration: Understanding how to use knowledge of prefixes to change the meaning of a base word; for example, "undone", "remove" and "misunderstand"
EALDElaboration: •building word families from morphemes under study to allow EAL/D students to efficiently expand their vocabulary and increase their comprehension

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Understand how to apply knowledge of common base words, prefixes, suffixes and generalisations for adding a suffix to a base word to read and comprehend new multimorphemic words
Elaboration: Using generalisations for adding a suffix to a base word to form a plural or past tense; for example, to make a word plural when it ends in "ss", "sh", "ch" or "z" add "es"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phoneme-grapheme (sound-letter) relationships and less common letter patterns to spell words
Elaboration: Using phonic knowledge to explore less common letter patterns after short vowels; for example, words that end in "dge" - "badge", "edge" and "fridge"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Use phoneme-grapheme (sound-letter) relationships and less common letter patterns to spell words
Elaboration: Using phonic knowledge and knowledge of letter patterns to spell words with 3-letter blends; for example, "str-ip"

Subject: English
ContentDescription: Recognise and know how to write most high-frequency words, including some homophones
Elaboration: Using context and syntactic knowledge to spell homophones; for example, "break" or "brake" and "ate" or "eight"
EALDElaboration: EAL/D students may benefit from: •Introducing and reinforcing high frequency words in context to support both spelling and correct use, as many of these words hold little meaning if not contextualised; for example ‘could’
